Made some minor tweaks to Pentland Designs' US coin sorter.

-Adjusted the base and coin sleeves to hold the same amounts as actual bank rolls ($0.50 for pennies, $2.00 for nickels, $5.00 for dimes, and $10.00 for quarters).

-Fixed the floating piece on the connector on top of the base.

-Included versions of coin sleeves with and without text.

-Included the gear, spinner, and hopper found in his parametric coin sorter, as well as added a crank handle.*

-Included separate versions of each individual part and each individual coin sleeve.

*Note: the gears and the crank handle work somewhat ok, but they are not all that great.

If you experience any trouble with the tolerance on the hopper, please see the post printing section below for instructions on how to fix the problem.

DISCLAIMER:
While the coin sleeves should theoretically hold the correct amounts of coins, please count all coins to double check before rolling them and taking them to the bank. I am not responsible for incorrectly rolled coins.

Video:
https://youtu.be/imBWtzQ9bAI

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

5% on base; 10% on everything else

Fixing the Hopper:

Unfortunately, I had a bit of trouble with the tolerance on the hopper which made it unable to connect to the base. I ended up having to use a pair of pliers to bend the part in a couple places to adjust the tolerance. I know this is a very unprofessional way of solving the problem, but the main reason I created this remix in the first place was just for my own personal use, so I didn't really mind doing it.

Because tolerance can vary quite a bit between different printers and different print settings, this extra step may or may not be necessary for you, but if it is, I'm sorry for the inconvenience.

It's kind of hard to describe in words, so I have attached a couple of pictures that will hopefully help a little bit. As you can see, all that needs to be done is to bend each side of the connection ever so slightly outward until the piece can fit on top of the base. (I know the pics aren't great but it's hard to take a picture with one hand lol.)

comments.text: My Monoprice Maker Select doesn't seem to like these files, it managed to print the hopper and spinner, but everything else the extruder was just frozen in place, not extruding or moving, just heating.  What's unfortunate is that this happens on almost every single model I've tried, some of them with the extruder "freezing" after it's gotten so far in the print, which is even more annoying.  Could anyone offer some advice?
comments.author: Precision3DPrinting

comments.text: Hmm...sounds like a problem with the printer itself maybe. I wish could help you out but I'm not really familiar with the Monoprice Maker Select so I don't know what to tell you. I really hope you can get it working. Sorry to hear about that.
comments.author: Precision3DPrinting

comments.text: Hello! Can I use Euro for this coinsorter, or do you have a model for euro
comments.author: Holzmichl

comments.text: Sorry I am quite late responding. I haven't been able to check Thingiverse in awhile. Unfortunately, this model is only for US coins, and I do not have a model for Euros. However, I am pretty sure that Pentland Designs, who created the sorter this model is based on, has made a Euro coin sorter. I would suggest checking there if you are still looking for one.
comments.author: Holzmichl

comments.text: I printed this version of the coin sorter, and I have to say that although I appreciate the correct sizing of the tubes for the coins, yeah, the gears are pretty bad. I print on a Taz 5 which I have dialed in to great tolerances, and these gears are VERY loose. Pretty much just for show. Also, the handle nub could easily be improved if you made it graduate in diameter. You have enough play where you could have it overhang a bit, thereby using friction to hold it in place. Again, with the tolerances I am used to, the handle just falls through the hole with room to spare. I don't even think I can fill the gap.
comments.author: ptraugot

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. The correctly sized coin sleeves were really the main reason I made this, and while looking at the parametric coin sorter by Pentland Designs, I decided to throw in the gears as a bit of an afterthought. He had said that he hadn't tested them himself but I decided to include them in my remix anyways.
comments.author: ptraugot

comments.text: No prob. Not criticizing your work. But goes to show how these printers all differ.

title: Battery Bracket for HobbyKing X666 frame

description.text: This is a battery bracket for a HobbyKing X666 quadrocopter frame. Aligns with mounting holes already on the bottom of the frame. Print with supports and 100% infill for best results. Two elastics are required to stop the battery from sliding out of the bracket. The elastic hooks can also allow for quick attachment of additional accessories.
Print 2 brackets with supports and 100% infill for best results.

comments.text: Nice job! This works perfectly! It's strong, holds the battery tight and i like how you can add other items onto/under the battery via elastics. I hung a WiFi Pineapple there and now have a mobile hacking platform!
comments.author: nadeaup

author: Njordan311

description.text:
Update: I fixed the clips the hold the upper scaffolding to the three body units. The clips look small, but I have tested them. They DO hold up to clipping and unclipping the scaffolding - at leasts enough to adjust them - for glueing.

While the excellent revision of the Eagle Transporter by Mirco211 was very nice, it was not perfect for my Makerbot Replicator 5th ed. I did not need his supports and who doesn't fiddle with a model.

On my revision, I decided to remodel the 'vernier thrusters' on each pod-leg. I wanted them to be printed without supports and have cones free. Moreover since I wanted the model to print smaller I simplified the geometry so that they entire object when printed was strong enough to be freed from the printed bed and painted without falling apart.

I recommend printing this at 200% (or more) on a typical fused filament fabrication 3D printer. I made my model small just because it was easier to work with in miniature.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

10%

Model rocket. Will fit C and D sized rocket motors. Made this rocket from a college CAD course. I have printed 4 of these rockets and they work like a charm. Overall height is around 340mm.

Inspired by: printedrockets.com (See site for additional instructions)

Other required parts:
Shock Cord (Rubber band that connects the Cone to the Body)
Parachute
Flame retardant paper (to protect parachute from melting)
Rocket motor (D12-0 or D12-3 seem to work the best) C size motors also fit
15 - 20 Grams of molding clay must be molded into the inside tip of the nosecone for stability

Have fun!

title: Saga of the Nine Worlds (2.5 Edition)

description.text:
In my never-ending quest to refine my Pocket-Tactics games, I present Saga of the Nine Worlds! Optimized for both printing ease and expedition, these pieces are smaller, more durable, and print without need of support or assembly.   
This set returns to Pocket-Tactics roots, starting players off with a simple rules set and an eye toward expansion. I'll be making some upgrade packs and other factions in this style if you all like it, so feedback is much appreciated.  
-Dutchmogul  
NOTE- The current stat sheet is a temporary file and I'll post the new one as soon as the art is finished....
Printed mine at a .1 layer height with 1 shell and 10% infill.

comments.text: Are these hex tiles the same size as Pocket Dungeon?
comments.author: ssrjazz

comments.text: Oh, yeah, they should all be 30mm hexes.
comments.author: ssrjazz

comments.text: I had a lot of failed prints on the Trollspan Warriors. The overhang of the clubs are too steep. I was able to eventually get a print to come out, but I did lose a lot of plastic and time. I recommend trying to improve the geometry on these guys.
comments.author: lewismoten

comments.text: The Trollspawn_Warr_x3 crashes Makerware, I ran them through Netfabb and got a repaired set that work.  If you like I can send you the repaired mesh or make a derivative and post..
comments.author: rocketboy

comments.text: Hey Guys, I started printing the first tiles and I am preparing the figures and of course reading through the sheets of all factions :D I was wondering if there is a forum where to discuss/ ask about pocket-tactics?
comments.author: EZ8-D

comments.text: I second this notion. The biggest problem I'm having is sorting through all the editions and variations and figuring out what to print and what the current rules are. Some sort of forum for sorting it all out would be great.
comments.author: EZ8-D

comments.text:
Yeah lets all waste our money on some satanic cult games dragging out souls to hell.
I say: Dont do it man ! Download and print something that will benefit you or others, as well as something that would cost you more buying from the store.
Dont be an idiot.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: Ah, so this is what one of these bot-generated messages looks like. You can almost see a pattern in the garbled nonsense. Fascinating!
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: I've just finished building my printer and this will be first of the "larger" projects to print (still awaiting 3 more coloured filaments to arrive though. Congrats on Featured - well deserved! Have you printedthose in ABS or PLA? What printer are you using?
comments.author: HEC

comments.text: Hey, thanks, and congrats on the printer! I actually print on a Replicator 1, and until I get around to upgrading the extruder (I'm a horrible procrastinator) I can only print in ABS. Works really well, though I'd prefer to be printing in PLA to be sure.
comments.author: HEC

comments.text: Hi, two quick questions in regards your (brief) instructions - 0.1 layer is that in mm? For 1 shell - does that apply for vertical shels as well? Thank you!
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Heh, I really wish I knew what that meant. I use the settings in RepG. I'm certain that the .1 is in mms (or .10. as it were... same thing, I guess). I'm guessing you're using slic3r or something? I would just print these the same way you would print anything else. Their design isn't so deviant that they require a special setup.
comments.author: HEC

comments.text: Thanks for the prompt reply.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Great idea. Am I allowed to translate the rules to german language?
comments.author: bigpaddi

comments.text: Absolutely! Email me a copy if you do. I'd love to have that available.
comments.author: bigpaddi

comments.text: Would you mind including dxf's for the hexagonal game tiles? It seems like they would be ideal for lasercutting.

description.text: 3D printable socks holder specific for washing machine.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low/very low

How does it work?

Before to put the laundry in the washing machine, you have only to insert the couple of socks in the tentacles of Soktopus, it will take them together during the washing cycle and you will recover the paired socks at the end of it.

Soktopus has also a little tentacle specifically designed to hang it on clothesline, in this way it will take care of your socks untill you will put them in your underwear drawer.

MOre info

Soktopus is designed to be printed with desktop 3D printer. I suggest you to print it using PLA or ABS (with heated printing bed), I made some tests and it is ok for washing untill 60°C.

title: Glass Adjustable Bed Brackets  - for 3/16" Glass - REMIX

description.text:
I remixed these before I saw DrLex and schlegipegi remixes. These fit Borosilicate Glass Sheets - 9" x 6" x 3/16" from McMaster-Carr. https://www.mcmaster.com/#8476k74/=16zaiuk

Use the threaded rod and knurled nut from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1949142.

Notice the Right and Left Rear brackets are off-set as needed to fit the bed better.

I have been using them for a year they work great on an CTC Replicator dual.

Printer:

CTC Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30% or more

comments.text: Could you put a dial gauge hooked up to the hot end carriage/ X smooth rods  and the bed and see what happens when you adjust the brackets to hold the glass firmly and tell what happens  ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: No change, the glass stays snug to the bed and doesn't push it off.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Then show the dial gauge when tightening the screws, measure to be made at the 4 corners and the middle.  I only trust measures.
comments.author: PCFlyer

comments.text: I have used these for a year, I wouldn't have posted it if I didn't work.  Make it yourself and see.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
What advantage to simple steel clips holding firmly the glass against the base plate and distributed at the best place which are not the corners ? Simple, strong, effective, easy to remove the glass .... Accurate positioning in the XY plane is not important, just the Z that is.
Here I doubt it will press the glass as the plastic corner will rotate, deform when the screws are tightened. Only a dial gauge can show.
SO, no advantage, just added complexity and potential inaccuracy.
comments.author: PCFlyer

comments.text: In my experience the clips are typically in the way and the extruder smacks them at some point in the build.  When the extruder hits the clips, a clip will either fly off and or shake the unit enough to create inaccuracy.  These corner brackets are flush with the top of the glass. Other benefit, unscrewing them slightly allows the bed to come off as opposed to removing 4 clips, then having to find 4 clips to put on again later.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I made my own clips with steel strips (before I used spring steel wire). No problem whatsoever.
Anyway, I fail to understand why you don't want to measure what happens.
People here are funny, lot of talks, lot of "it works", "it is the best", "great" but no figures, no measure yet everything is in the micron range :-)
comments.author: PCFlyer

comments.text: A year of successful use is enough proof for me. Steel strips aren't printable - hence not a solution for many.  If you have dust or debris under the glass your bed height will change at the micron level, steel clips or not.  A simple removable glass bed is a nice feature, easy to cool down and remove parts without torquing on the the machine.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
This guy thinks otherwise and as I already suggested to others copies of this system, put a lip to ensures the glass plate is pressed against the bed.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2218805
comments.author: PCFlyer

comments.text: Operator error.  There is nothing wrong with this solution. Good luck saving the world from it.
comments.author: MKSA

author: PCFlyer

description.text:
When I made this wall mount for a tissue box I decided to make it customizable. Can be used to make a wall mount for a lot of square things...

It is possible to break the model if you enter impossible combinations of screw head size and thickness etc. So pay attention to the model before you print.

comments.text: Good idea! Although I would've expected it to require less plastic; It's just a tissue box after all. Also, I'm sure there is a way to hide the screws underneath the box. This were my two cents! :) Good job, though! And thanks for your contribution to this community!
comments.author: jpmorand

comments.text: Yes. It is way too sturdy for that tissue box the way I printed it. In the parametric model you can adjust it to be much thinner. And you are right about the screws. If I get the time I will try to improve the model. But until then the people that might need a wall holder for something can customise and hopefully end up with a solution they like.

title: JPL Badge Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a badge holder designed for common ID cards and PIV card.
It is NOT GSA FIPS 201 Approved or HSPD-12 Compliant, but still cool.

The tab at the bottom is designed for the badge to slip out pretty easily and then snap back in. A slot on the back also allows easy scanning of a Bar-Code without having to remove the badge. The JPL logo on the back can be replaced with another (a blank STL is provided).

The JPL Badge Sliders ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2215454 ) are used with this to make a logo visible on the front of the card.

Print flat. No supports needed.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fuwkleHskoQ

description.text:
I wanted a small case that fit my C.H.I.P. that would fit a 30mm fan for cooling. I couldn't find one, so I designed one. While the fan is a 5VDC unit, it's plugged into the C.H.I.P. ground and 3.3VDC and runs very quietly, while still pushing plenty of air to cool this little guy. The battery compartment is sized to accommodate the 4000mAh battery that came with the original Kickstarter campaign, but the SCAD files are attached for tweaking to your heart's content.

Additionally, you'll notice that there are heat sinks installed. I bought some bulk, small (14mmx14mmx6mm) heat sinks and put one on each of the major chips on my C.H.I.P. to help dissipate heat.

author: Mstef

description.text:
With this MTG box you can take your deck and all your dice with you. This way you don't have to mess around with different boxes just to play a game. It will hold to much dice for you to use in one game (even when you play a full scale token game!) and it will fit a deck of around 70 cards max with protective sleeves.

For this model you'll need a 2mm iron bar.

At the moment this model is still in progress. Soon I will work on a way to lock the box so it won't open during traveling. When I fixed that I will also upload the box for Plains, Islands, Forests, Mountains and Swamps.

title: Philips Respironics Amara View Quick-Release Tube to SYS1HT15 Heated Tube Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter to connect the System One 60 Series Heated CPAP Tubing by Phillips Respironics - SYS1HT15 to the Amara View Quick-Release Tube.

For some reason Philips decided that the quick release tube should not connect to their heated tube. So you are force to use the friction fit end of the heated tube on the mask itself, making it difficult to disconnect the mask from the tube, especially in the dark and half asleep!

This adapter will allow you to use the quick release tube, making removing the mask quick and easy. It's obvious which end goes where, as one end is a different size.

description.text:
Parakeet PCB beak style case

This is a case for the Parakeet board designed by mzst123

The case measures 5.5cm x 4.4cm x 2.6cm with a "beak" or wedge shape along one side.

It is designed to fit a specific battery, model 523450 (3.7v 1000 mAh) which I measured at 52mm x 34.5mm x 5.3mm. There is a bit of space left for a slightly wider battery, up to 40mm max. I left the extra clearance to ensure the wixel antenna can get a good signal from as many angles as possible.

Battery capacity shouldn't really go much below 1000 mAh because the SIM800 needs the potential for high burst current drain and the charging resistor would also need to be adjusted accordingly. This battery capacity has been giving over 2 days battery life.

I mounted the JST XH battery connector at 90 degrees to fit more neatly and reduce the assembled board height (by bending the connector legs using a hard surface) I also used a flat plastic spacer attached to the underside of the battery to provide extra insulation and physical protection between the battery and the board.

Only the external antenna socket was used with the supplied SIM800 plug in antenna. I didn't solder on the fixed antenna because the flat one has a lower profile and has always worked well for me. There is a small groove allowing for the gsm antenna to be mounted above the wixel antenna at 90 degrees against the side of the case.

The photos show the design printed in White ABS plastic (vapor smoothed) with a 100 micron setting. This gave a really nice result, feeling strong and light and with the LEDs visible through the case. Printed via 3dhubs.

Whenever working with lithium batteries, be sure you have studied and fully understand the safety considerations concerning these. Soldering the battery wires, using a battery incorrectly, short circuiting, using the wrong type of battery for a circuit or damaging the battery can result in a battery fire.

I would only ever crimp connectors, use high quality batteries from a reputable source and ones with built in protection circuits. Always being very careful to protect the battery from short circuit, physical damage or extremes of temperature. Any project you undertake is at your own risk.

Parakeet project page:

https://jamorham.github.io/#parakeet

This is a tensioner for the y-axis on the TronXY X1. This will also fit any 2040 aluminum extrusion. The goal was to make a very sturdy tensioner that didn't slide or shake while keeping the belt and pulley as rotationally controlled as possible. I borrowed design elements from other tensioners. However, this was modeled from scratch in blender. I left it rather blocky as to keep with the straight lines of the extrusions. I feel that this is a very strong and sturdy tensioner. It uses the same hardware that came with the printer with the exception of the the m5 x 30mm bolt and m5 nut for the actual tension piece and the 3X m3 x 40mm bolts that go through the shaft. Enjoy and leave some comments.

UPDATE: I noticed some rubbing when the belt moves fast. I realized that the center of the idle pulley was not centered vertically on the channel for the extrusion. I have fixed it and will be printing out a test for myself. Just wanted to get this fix out asap. This now includes a compatible knob.

UPDATE: I fixed some of the tolerances. Things fit a bit better now. As well as got rid of the weird curvy part on the bottom. This matches the x-tensioner I have uploaded. So, now they are a set with the same design.

UPDATE 4/19/17: On the side where the wheel of the carriage comes to the end of the extrusion was blocked and reduced the print area. This has been removed per feedback from a maker. The cap has also been adjusted to be more of the proper size.

title: Raspberry Pi 3 Anet A8 mount (no drilling/no screws/no support)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Why?

I've tried to come up with a solution to mount my Raspberry Pi 3 (for running OctoPrint) to the Anet A8 without the need to drill holes into the printer's frame. And to make things a little more challenging, I tried to do so without the need for support material. :)

The mount

The parts themselves feel pretty flimsy and assembly is a bit tricky, but once everything's in place, the whole construction is actually quite solid.

I consider this mount beta (sort of): it works, but it definitely could be improved - feedback is welcome!

Assembly

  • Start by sliding the longest part #1 from the narrower top of the frame (mainboard side) towards the bottom with the "claws" pointing towards the print bed.
  • Do the same for part #2, but don't push them all the way down yet!
  • Slide parts #3 between the crossbars (#1 and #2) and the printer frame (from the back) and make sure to push them into their slots.
  • Push part #1 and part #2 down until everything fits tight.
  • Clip the Raspberry Pi in place.
  • Done. :)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used black PLA from Esun.

  • Bed: 60°C
  • Hotend: 210°C

comments.text: Just wanted to say that I just got started in 3D printing, have been printing some basic stuff for my Anet A8, installed Octopi on my Raspberry Pi 3 and was looking for a way to mount.  Was a little skeptical of this design due to how simple it is, but it works pretty amazing!  It definitely holds sturdy and didn't require any screws or drilling or anything.  It's a little hard to get it together at first, and there are only a few points it grabs the board without blocking ports, but I found the right spot and it's rock solid!  Great work!

title: New Finger for Prosthetic Hand (progressive and independent finger movement)

description.text:
This is a new finger for the Prosthetic Hand (progressive and independent finger movement) that is located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220942. This finger allows for more movement and should be used in place of the fingers on the previously posted hand. This design was created by Bob Roth from Tulsa, OK. and he has been gracious enough to share the design with our community of makers. This project is an extension of the work being done by Robohand, Ivan Owen, Jorge Zuniga, and the e-NABLE group. This work is being done in my lab at the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee. For more info see:
http://frankieflood.blogspot.com/2014/01/prosthetic-hand-milwaukee-prt3-bob-roth.html
http://frankieflood.blogspot.com/2014/01/prosthetic-hand-milwaukee-prt4.html Update: Ivan Owen added supports for Bob's finger design so this can be printed without supports. Ivan wrote the following: "I took the STL files and used design software to add in supports only where they are absolutely needed to print the finger. The resulting STL is attached. I tested it on my Makerbot Rep 2 using a 0.25mm layer thickness, 2 shells and 10% infill and no software generated supports. The result was a pretty nice print." In addition some of the e-NABLE group needed the files separated into smaller groups of parts so they could print on a smaller build platform. I have separated Ivan's file into two sets of parts. For more information on where to connect with people who can help someone in need with sizing, printing and/or assembly a mechanical hand please join the e-NABLE Google+ Community entitled, e-NABLE:
https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
For more information and stories:
http://enablingthefuture.org
https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization

author: Bart8

description.text:
Hello Guys,

Today I bring you a cool little project that would benefit vision impaired people and also those of you that can not stop and may need a cube to play with.

The main reason why I design this cube was because I wanted to help a friend of mine learn braille in a interactive way. After thinking for a few hours and 4 prototypes, I believe that this one is a good design as it has smooth extruded balls that are easy to print and also are soft the the touch.

The dimensions : 20x20x20
The bolt and nut are : M3 20 or M3 15
Material : PLA
Speed : 60%
Layer : 0.2 mm

Hint for printing :
Print it with the face that has the nut trap down.

I hope you all have fun using it . Whether it is for you or as a gift for a friend to learn something new.

I will do a tutorial soon on my channel :D

Mr Jefferson105

How to use the cube :

The cube is made of 3 rotary sections , each section has 4 sides
-> side 1 : is a flat no balls
-> side 2 : has two balls
-> side 3 and 4: have 1 ball this is show single dots in any given layer .

The idea is similar to a rubrics cube , by rotating the side you solve the cube .
in this case you do so and you can make a single letter in one face, preferably the front face.

Example :

By rotating the faces so that the front face has 3 dots on the left hand side will show the letter "L" also this will show that the cube has been assemble properly.

title: Tronxy X3 Y-Axis(or 2020 extrusion) Wheel Tensioner

description.text:
Alright So I uploaded a version with the correct dimensions, Im not sure what happened but my bed dimensions were off. Choose the first file if you are using the original y-axis carriage or choose the second file if you want 40mmx80mm spacing or are using my bed carriage here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185496.

Be aware that the inherent issue with wobbly y-axis may still be present with the new version, as the spacing on the stock holes is 42mm (as far as I can tell) this seems to be to far apart for the wheels to properly tighten, I was able to easily modify my stock bed to fit this and I recommend doing that as 80x40 spacing is much better. I will print this version as soon as a I have a chance and test it.

I made this wheel tensioner because I was sick of having to, undo the screws, try to fit two tools in there while someone manhandled the printer, plus clamp the wheels so they stayed tensioned, just to tension the y-axis wheels. It works remarkably well(with just one screw driver and no moving the printer). The version Im uploading has a few new features compared to the one that I printed initially, I havent tested this version, but the only main difference is it has a few bridges that might cause some troubles now(but are necessary for the screws to fit recessed without having to use a drill...like I did). The counter bore may need some work, so if anyone prints this and it doesn't work let me now and ill change it. It is 8mm thick so if your someone who counts every mm of your z axis travel(but never even goes near half of it lol), take that into account. If you want to use it for something other than the tronxy X3 the screw spacing is 40mm x 80mm.

It will be fairly tight as is (depending on your printers accuracy) and only needs a very small amount of clamping to make a difference. So put the M4 screws and nuts in and keep them loose then slide it on the extrusion and just snug them up, it wont need a lot...there will be a torque at the base of the standoff that will make the arm want to twist radially outward (probably the major weakpoint I can think of for this system) so it will probably continue to tighten with little more effect, other than to eventually break and twist the wheel until it is improperly seated in the v slot...keep it in mind.

I just reused the M5 screws that came with the printer, although for 2 of the corners it could probably use some shorter screws and it will need m5 nuts.

The holes on the side are for m4 screws and nuts.

I havent used the belt holder yet but it should work.

You'll need two of the clamps and an m4 screw and nut.

I didnt make the clamp(I just split it into a single stl) so credit where it is due to Wisnaeme
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2082259/#files

If you print this, any comments on how I can improve it would appreciated.

Printer:

TronXY X3

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50

description.text: I made this miniature with the intent to use for the tabletop mecha war game: Mobile Frame Zero, and a lack of legos. I plan to make accessories that can snap onto the slots on this figure's shoulders. chest, legs, and arms to to act as the various systems that can go onto a mecha for the Mobile Frame Zero game as well as to allow for the mini to be aesthetically customize-able. While looking for reference photos to approximate the size of a standard MFZ mini made of legos I figured that they were about 6 lego bricks tall or about 2 1/2" tall, which is roughly the size of the Iron Golem miniature I had made a while back. This also means that this miniature can be used alongside other 28mm scale miniatures as well. It should stand on its own so making a base for it is optional. Hopefully I can get around to making an accessory pack for this soon so it doesn't look so plain and so it can be used in MFZ games.

description.text:
This is a 3D-printable spectrophotometer based on a TCD1304 linear CCD and standard 35mm camera optics.

The resolution is ~1nm (the Na-doublet at 589nm is just exactly not resolvable).

The total price of the components depends on how cheaply you can scavenge them on that auction site, but expect to pay something like this:
Optics: 2x 10$, CCD: 10$, MCU: 15$, Grating: 3$, A few $$ for misc. parts.
Total: ~60$

The design

The spectrometer is a lens-grating-lens design:

The diffraction grating is a cheap transmission grating slide. Both lenses are pentax SMC-M 50mm f/2, which are easy to find and cheap.

The grating constant is 1000 lp/mm and the lower wavelength is chosen to be 380 nm as the lenses start absorbing here. From 760 nm second order diffraction starts to overlap so 760 nm is chosen as the upper limit for the spectrum.

Inserting these values into the diffraction equation gives angles of diffracted light from 22.3°-49.5°. The center angle is 35.9°, which is the angle between the two optical axes of the lenses.

The CCD (TCD1304) is 29.1 mm long and and with a bit of trigonometry we end up with an ideal focal length of 60mm for the focusing lens. A bit higher than the 50mm actually used, so a part of the CCD remains unused.

Step 1: Print

Download .scad files. If you have a different grating calculate the center angle and modify the parameter 1st in the file poly-definitions.scad

Modify the files slit-holder.scad, and magnet.scad to fit your magnets. Make sure that the CCD-PCB matches the holes in the spectrometer box.

Print everything. Mind you that the spectrometer box will take ~18 hours to print.

Lenses

Strip the lenses.

  1. Unscrew and remove the bayonett.
  2. Unscrew and remove the aperture coupling together with any screws you find.
  3. Unscrew front ring.
  4. Again remove any screws you come by.
  5. Remove the front lens group.
  6. Remove the aperture iris.
  7. Remove the lens barrel from the focusing helicoid.
  8. Reassemble the front and back lens groups.

They should now look like this:

Insert the lenses in the lens holders and secure them with some of the left-over screws.

The linear CCD module

The spectrometer uses a TCD1304 linear CCD driven by a ST Micro Nucleo F401. The firmware can be found here https://tcd1304.wordpress.com/

A computer running linux or macos is required to communicate with the CCD module. There's a 3rd party Windows client as well.

Populate the CCD PCB. It should look like this:

Insert the PCB in the spectrometer box using M3 hex-screws (don't use philips, it's hard to fit a screwdriver inside the spectrometer). Use 3 springs from ball-point pens between the PCB and the spectrometer wall. They will act as a primitive kinematic mount.

The slit
  1. Fit the magnet into the slit-holder and cut a DE-razor blade to make a slit.
  2. Insert two 10mm M3 screws in the two lower screw-holes of the spectrograph (the holes will be inaccessible later).
  3. Mount the slit-holder with two 16mm M3 screws and two pieces of ballpoint-pen-spring.
Assembly and focus

Insert the lenses into the spectrograph and secure them using two M3 screws.

Focus the slit using an autocollimation procedure: Place a small mirror after the focusing lens and a flashlight in front of the slit as show here:

Use the reflection of the slit onto itself to focus.

The grating

Insert the grating slide. You will probably have to cut a few mm's of the sides to make it fit.

You will now have something looking like this:

You can now use a laser pointer to bring the CCD roughly into focus.

Sample accessories

Fit the magnets inside the magnet-holder:

Secure it to the spectrometer:

Assemble the cell-holder:

Click it on the spectrograph:

The light source

Still a work in progress..

Focus the CCD

Use different laser pointers to bring the CCD into focus. Focus first using a blue laser adjusting only the screws to the left. Then focus a red laser, adjusting the screw to the right. Do a few iterations until you don't see improvements. Each laser should produce the most narrow line possible:

If you did everything properly, you should be able to make a recording of a CFL-lamp with greater detail than I have here:

Hardware
  1. Linear CCD module (Nucleo F401re, TCD1304DG, CCD-PCB)
    check out https://tcd1304.wordpress.com or my HAD-project page https://hackaday.io/project/9829-linear-ccd-module
  2. 2x Pentax SMC-M 50mm f/2
  3. A small assortment of magnets
  4. A DE-razor blade
  5. Diffraction grating slide (1000 lines/mm)
Software
  1. Linux (any distro will do), macos (Sierra works, probably others as well. You can even use windows with Jens-Ulrich Fröhlichs java-based GUI.
  2. TCD1304 driver firmware for STM32F401RE (UART)
  3. GUI or CLI (UART)
    Both are available from tcd1304.wordpress.com

For an Octave extended GUI visit http://science.jefro.de/

Just a brace to glue onto a pair of Sony bluetooth headphones to fix some broken swivels.

comments.text: Love the headphones, but after a couple of drops the cheap plastic elements that enable some swiveling snapped in half.
